Sir George Catlin: Hopkins'only peer
By ANDY SANGEORGE
Although there are many
Hopkins professors listed in
Who's Who, there's probably
only one included in the English
peerage.
Sir George Catlin, a visiting
professor in Political Science,
says that he is more of a
politician than an academic. Even
so many of his students from the
35 universities he has taught at,
from Heidelberg to Peking to
McGill, to members of the British
Parliament will testify that he
knows his way in the world of
politics.
In 1926 the white-haired
yrofessor came to the United
States to head the Rockefeller
Investigation on Prohibition. In
that way he had an influence on
the U.S. Constitution, Years later
he met with Mahatma Ghandi in
India; once while the Mahatma
was in the bathtub. In that way
he was involved with India
independence, a major change in
Asia.
He has served as an advisor to
Labor Party leader Arthur
Greenwood, six American
Presidents, and one also-ran,
Wendell Wilkie. Along with H.G.
Wells he co-founded Realist
Magazine. But his career in
politics is still going on.
Presidently Sir George is an
advisor to Harold Wilson as an
expert on International Affairs,
while his daughter serves as the

Secretary of the Interior for
Wilson's Shadow Labor
Government.
So much a part of his life is
commited to politics that he has
written his autobiography, which
will appear soon, with the title
For God's Sake Go!. It's aimed at
the defeat of lhe- present Prime
Minister Edward Heath, which
Catlin expects in the next British
election.
Much of his dislike of Heath is
based on his opposition to
Britain's entry in a Common
Market dominated by the
French. "I am not opposed to
the Common Market as such, but
am opposed to French
domination of the Common
Market. French policy is
French-centered. It always has
been and it is now. We must
recognize that this is so," Catlin
asserts.
Turning to another major
topic in British political life Sir
George Catlin says that Ireland
must be regarded as a united
country. As a solution to the
fighting he suggests that a
committee of British jurors draft
a bill of minority rights to
protect both Catholics and
Protestants. He concludes that if
the Irish do not accept
reasonable terms, the British
soldiers should be withdrawn
because it is wrong to sacrifice
other British subjects for Irish
hard-headedness.

Commenting on recent U.S.
foreign policy, he asserts, "The
U.S. State Department has been
too concerned with Vietnam to
shape a European policy."
Sir George says that he has
been delighted with Hopkins in
terms of students, faculty and
Baltimore, but he doesn't just
confine himself to the
Homewood campus, even for the
term of his visiting professorship.
This semester he lectures at
eight other campuses located in
Maryland, Washington,
Massachusetts and Texas. And
still that isn't all He has begun a
new book called Politics Today:
The Shake Up.
When asxed how he manages
to fit his own research into his
jam-packed teaching schedule, he
replies in characteristic English
manner: "I simply follow
Priestly's advice and put the seat
of the pants to the seat of the
chair."
